title: Finding hidden growth opportunities in your product | Albert Cheng (Duolingo, Grammarly, Chess.com)
key_insights: Growth is about connecting users to the value of your product, not just metrics hacking
Use explore and exploit framework: find the right mountain to climb, then focus resources on climbing it effectively
When you find a winning experiment, share insights broadly across the company for 10X impact
For consumer subscription products, user retention is gold - without it, you're forced to monetize on day one
Hire for high agency, clock speed, and energy rather than just deep experience - sometimes experience can be a crutch
Make your free product reflect everything your paid product can offer to maximize conversion rates
Focus on positive reinforcement over negative feedback to drive engagement (80% of users review games after wins, not losses)
Aim for 30-40% D1 retention as a baseline for consumer apps to have mathematical chance of growth
topics_discussed: Explore vs exploit framework for finding growth opportunities
Biggest monetization win at Grammarly through sampling paid features
Game review positivity experiment at Chess.com (25% growth in reviews)
Building experimentation culture from 0 to 1000 experiments per year
Consumer subscription business model best practices
Screenshot tracking to identify viral moments at Duolingo
AI integration in growth work and product development
Company culture differences between Duolingo, Grammarly, and Chess.com
Hiring for high agency over experience

memorable_quotes: Growth as the job is to connect users to the value of your product. Growth sometimes gets this reputation that it's just pure metrics hacking.
User retention is gold for consumer subscription companies. If you don't retain your users, then a lot of the onus is on getting them to pay on day one.
Sometimes experience could be a crutch, especially in this world where the grounds are shifting so fast with AI. A lot of your learned habits actually need to be intentionally discarded.
frameworks_mentioned: Growth Model and User Journey Mapping
Gamification Three Pillars (Core Loop, Metagame, Profile)
The Green Machine (Duolingo's product development playbook)
summary: Albert Cheng shares tactical frameworks and real examples from leading growth at Duolingo, Grammarly, and Chess.com, focusing on his explore/exploit methodology for finding growth opportunities and building experimentation culture. The conversation provides actionable insights on consumer subscription growth, user retention strategies, and scaling experimentation programs.
